channel.title: NYT > Top Stories
channel.copyright: Copyright 2022 The New York Times Company

item.title: Democrats, on Defense in Blue States, Brace for a Red Wave in the House
item.description: “Reality is setting in”: With two weeks to go, Republicans are competing in Democratic bastions like New York, California, Oregon and even Rhode Island.
item.dc:creator: Shane Goldmacher
item.media:credit: Philip Keith for The New York Times
item.media:description: Allan Fung, a Republican congressional candidate in Rhode Island, at a campaign event on Monday.

item.title: If These Poll Results Keep Up, Expect Anything on Election Night
item.description: The current range of numbers could translate to a Democratic hold in the Senate, or an overall Republican rout.
item.dc:creator: Nate Cohn

item.title: A Secret, Failed Oil Deal: How the U.S.-Saudi Relationship Ruptured
item.description: Ahead of President Biden’s trip to Saudi Arabia this summer, his administration thought it had secured pledges of increases in oil production throughout the year. The opposite happened.
item.dc:creator: Mark Mazzetti, Edward Wong and Adam Entous
item.category: Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries
Abdulaziz bin Salman, Prince of Saudi Arabia
item.media:description: President Biden arriving in Saudi Arabia in July. The administration thought it had secured a promise from the Saudis to keep oil flowing in a bid to stabilize prices.

item.title: How Saudi Arabia’s Blowup With Biden Threatens Democrats in 2022
item.description: Democrats and administration officials are furious at the Saudis’ move to cut oil production, seeing it as an attempt to meddle in a U.S. election.
item.dc:creator: Blake Hounshell
item.media:credit: Bandar Aljaloud/Saudi Royal Palace, via Associated Press
item.media:description: In this image released by the Saudi Royal Palace, Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman greeted President Biden in July in Jeddah, Saudi Arabia.

item.title: Liberal House Democrats Retract Call on Biden to Seek Cease-Fire in Ukraine
item.description: One day after issuing a letter urging President Biden to seek direct diplomatic talks with Russia, progressives withdrew that appeal. The move reflected deepening divisions over the conflict.
item.dc:creator: Catie Edmondson
item.media:credit: Gabriela Bhaskar for The New York Times
item.media:description: Representative Pramila Jayapal of Washington, the letter’s principal author, faulted unnamed aides for releasing the letter.

item.title: Germany’s Allies Challenge Its Stances on Ukraine and Energy
item.description: The government has dismissed criticism of its refusal to provide modern tanks to Ukraine and its massive energy subsidy for its own citizens. But its friends are bridling.
item.dc:creator: Steven Erlanger
item.media:description: Chancellor Olaf Scholz of Germany, right; Prime Minister Denys Shmyhal of Ukraine, center; and Ursula von der Leyen, president of the European Commission, at a conference in Berlin on Tuesday on the reconstruction of Ukraine. Germany has pushed back against the idea that it is isolating itself.

item.title: Biden Says Russian Use of a Nuclear Weapon Would Be a ‘Serious Mistake’
item.description: President Biden’s remarks reflect the urgent concern in Washington and among Western allies that Russia may be searching for a pretext to unleash a battlefield nuclear weapon.
item.dc:creator: David E. Sanger
item.media:credit: Finbarr O'Reilly for The New York Times
item.media:description: Ukrainian officials have accused Russia of secretly building dirty bombs at the Zaporizhzhia nuclear power plant.

item.title: Brittney Griner’s Prison Term Is Upheld by Russian Court
item.description: The W.N.B.A. athlete is facing nine years in a Russian prison on a drug charge. A prisoner swap may be her only path home.
item.dc:creator: Ivan Nechepurenko, Neil MacFarquhar and Jonathan Abrams
item.media:description: Brittney Griner speaking with her lawyers in a courtroom in July. Addressing the court on Tuesday, she protested her unusually long sentence.

item.title: Rishi Sunak’s Challenge: Unifying the Party and Fixing the Economy
item.description: The Conservative Party is fractured and Britain’s public finances are battered. That will test the political skills of a leader who has been involved in national politics for only seven years.
item.dc:creator: Mark Landler
item.category: Charles III, King of the United Kingdom
item.media:description: Prime Minister Rishi Sunak of Britain speaks outside 10 Downing Street after taking office on Tuesday.

item.title: Who Are Rishi Sunak’s Top Cabinet Ministers?
item.description: The new prime minister named people with high-level experience, several of them to posts they have held before, sending a message of stability after a period of upheaval.
item.dc:creator: Megan Specia
item.media:description: Prime Minister Rishi Sunak of Britain appointed cabinet members on Tuesday, mostly drawing on lawmakers who have held prominent positions in the past.

item.title: Some Britons fear Sunak is too rich to understand working-class suffering.
item.description: A British worker earning the median wage would have to have been working since the Stone Age to amass the new prime minister’s fortune, one group estimated.
item.dc:creator: Emma Bubola
item.media:description: Rishi Sunak, left, and his wife, Akshata Murty, were estimated to be worth more than $800 million, according to The Times of London.

item.title: How a Pro-Nazi Camp on Long Island Inspired a New Play
item.description: Bess Wohl sees “Camp Siegfried,” which opens Off Broadway in November, as a “deeply American play” about seduction.
item.dc:creator: Alexis Soloski
item.media:description: The entrance to the camp.

item.title: Adidas Ends Partnership With Kanye West After Antisemitic Comments
item.description: The German sportswear giant is the latest company to cut ties with Mr. West, now known as Ye, after his antisemitic remarks. Ending the partnership is expected to hurt company profits.
item.dc:creator: Melissa Eddy, Vanessa Friedman and Michael J. de la Merced
item.media:description: Kanye West, now known as Ye, in Hollywood in 2016 at an event promoting his partnership with Adidas.

item.title: James Corden and the Dangers of Likability
item.description: No one knows what an egg yolk omelet is, but we all know that TV hosts should be relatable. Or should they? That didn’t do Ellen DeGeneres any favors.
item.dc:creator: Jason Zinoman
item.category: The Late Late Show with James Corden (TV Program)
item.media:credit: Rebecca Smeyne for The New York Times
item.media:description: James Corden at a Tony Awards party in 2019. He presents himself as an ordinary bloke but is actually a Broadway star well known in Britain before arriving in the United States.

item.title: Painting Damaged by Beirut Explosion Is a Long-Lost Gentileschi
item.description: A painting that was scarred by the 2020 blast in Beirut is now attributed to Artemisia Gentileschi, the great 17th-century Italian painter known for her depiction of strong women.
item.dc:creator: Jori Finkel
item.media:credit: Brian Guido for The New York Times
item.media:description: “Hercules and Omphale,” by Artemisia Gentileschi, is being repaired at the Getty Museum’s conservation studio in Los Angeles. It had hung in the Sursock Palace in Beirut as an anonymous 17th-century painting.

item.title: The Try Guys and the Prison of Online Fame
item.description: This is what success looks like in the creator economy: Sometimes you have to beg millions of fans for mercy.
item.dc:creator: Willy Staley

item.title: Putin Is Onto Us
item.description: When it comes to energy, the West wants five incompatible things at once.
item.dc:creator: Thomas L. Friedman

item.title: Stroke and John Fetterman: What Society Should Know About the Brain’s Ability to Heal
item.description: What society can learn from John Fetterman’s stroke.
item.dc:creator: Jill Bolte Taylor
item.media:credit: Maddie McGarvey for The New York Times
item.media:description: Lt. Gov. John Fetterman of Pennsylvania campaigning in Greensburg, Pa., in May.

item.title: For New York Governor, The Times Endorses Kathy Hochul
item.description: In-person voting begins on Oct. 29.
item.dc:creator: The Editorial Board
item.media:credit: Jingyu Lin for The New York Times

item.title: To Understand Today’s G.O.P., You Have to Understand Trump’s Enablers
item.description: The journalist Mark Leibovich details the story behind the “sycophants” who bowed to the ex-president.
item.dc:creator: ‘The Ezra Klein Show’
item.category: Thank You for Your Servitude: Donald Trump's Washington and the Price of Submission (Book)

item.title: Your Tuesday Evening Briefing
item.description: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Cullen
item.media:credit: Philip Keith for The New York Times
item.media:description: Republican Congressional candidate Allan Fung on the campaign trail.

item.title: Some good news on energy
item.description: Renewable sources made up the vast majority of new generating capacity last year, a new report found. But the world’s energy transition still needs to speed up.
item.dc:creator: Ivan Penn
item.media:description: The Ivanpah Solar Electric Generating System in the Mojave Desert near Nipton, Calif.

item.title: Taylor Swift’s ‘Midnights’: Let’s Discuss
item.description: The blockbuster singer-songwriter’s 10th studio album finds her at a crossroads: Will she continue to reckon with her past, or forge another new path forward?

item.title: When You’re Sick at Home
item.description: Your guide to eating well, even when you’re feeling low.
item.dc:creator: Nikita Richardson
item.media:credit: Ben Russell for The New York Times
item.media:description: The smoked brisket pho from Lucy’s Vietnamese in Brooklyn makes for a perfect recovery meal.

item.title: For Disabled Workers, a Tight Labor Market Opens New Doors
item.description: With Covid prompting more employers to consider remote arrangements, employment has soared among adults with disabilities.
item.dc:creator: Ben Casselman
item.media:credit: Sarah Rice for The New York Times
item.media:description: Before the pandemic, Kathryn Wiltz repeatedly asked her employer to let her work from home because of her disability, but was denied.

item.title: Ashton B. Carter, Defense Secretary Under Obama, Dies at 68
item.description: Trained as a physicist, he opened the U.S. military to transgender service members and removed barriers to women in combat roles.
item.dc:creator: Clay Risen
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:description: Ashton B. Carter in 2016, near the end of his term as secretary of defense.

item.title: As Israel Votes, Again, Netanyahu Pins Hopes on the Far Right
item.description: To regain power, Benjamin Netanyahu, the longest-serving Israeli prime minister, will most likely need the support of Itamar Ben-Gvir, a far-right leader with a history of extreme views.
item.dc:creator: Patrick Kingsley
item.media:credit: Avishag Shaar-Yashuv for The New York Times
item.media:description: Itamar Ben-Gvir during a night walk with supporters on Thursday in Jerusalem.

item.title: Two Right-Wing Operatives Plead Guilty in 2020 Robocall Scheme
item.description: Jacob Wohl and Jack Burkman arranged thousands of robocalls that prosecutors said were intended to discourage residents of minority neighborhoods from voting by mail in 2020.
item.dc:creator: Christine Hauser
item.media:description: Jack Burkman, center, and Jacob Wohl, left, in 2018. Prosecutors said they used robocalls to intimidate residents in minority neighborhoods to refrain from voting by mail in 2020.

item.title: Uterine Cancer: What to Know About Symptoms and Treatment
item.description: A new study raised alarms about chemical hair straighteners being linked to the disease, but doctors say there are telltale symptoms to watch for.
item.dc:creator: Dani Blum

item.title: Is It Time to See a Sex Therapist?
item.description: Sex can be an important part of personal well-being. But sex therapists say the work they do remains misunderstood.
item.dc:creator: Catherine Pearson

item.title: How Black Women Can Interpret Those Scary Health Statistics
item.description: Doomsday headlines are nothing new. But over time they can damage your mental health if you’re not careful.
item.dc:creator: Jacquelynn Kerubo

item.title: Why Is Pickleball So Popular?
item.description: Everyone and their mother seems to be playing. What’s the draw — and is it really a workout?
item.dc:creator: Juno DeMelo
item.media:credit: Caleb Thal for The New York Times

item.title: Paul Mescal Has Been Working Things Out
item.description: The actor, who became a sudden sex symbol with Hulu’s “Normal People,” stars as another psychologically complex character in the A24 feature “Aftersun.”
item.dc:creator: Douglas Greenwood
item.media:credit: Tom Jamieson for The New York Times

item.title: How to Solve Hard Crosswords
item.description: Friday, Saturday and Sunday bring some of the hardest puzzles of the week.
item.dc:creator: Jackie Frere and Isaac Aronow
